The Libyan leader Muammar Gadafy today added his voice to growing calls from the Arab world for the immediate release of the two French journalists being held hostage in Iraq, following an unprecedented diplomatic campaign.

Col Gadafy said kidnapping foreigners in Iraq amounted to "terrorism" and that kidnappings were especially reprehensible when they involved "hostages from countries that stood against the war in Iraq".

Although he did not name the two hostages, Christian Chesnot of Radio France Internationale and Georges Malbrunot of Le Figaro, Col Gadafy made it clear he was asking for their release.

"I call on abductors of those hostages to free them immediately because this harms Islam," he said.

The Libyan leader's comments followed days of frantic diplomatic activity by the French government, which has refused to bow to the kidnappers' demands to scrap a ban on Muslim headscarves in schools.

The French foreign minister, Michel Barnier, has spent the past few days meeting leaders from across the Middle East and yesterday secured the assistance of Jordan, which has had success in similar situations. At least nine Jordanian hostages have been freed in Iraq in the last two weeks.

The kidnappings have stunned France, which vehemently opposed the US-led war in Iraq, and were widely condemned throughout the Arab world where many see France as an ally.

Yasser Arafat has called for the "immediate release" of the men, saying France was a friend of the Palestinian cause, while Jordan's King Abdullah II was quoted as telling Mr Barnier the abduction of the journalists "reflects the transgression committed by some against the ethics and values of benevolence and justice, which constitute the pillars of Islam".

Today Pope John Paul added his voice to calls for the journalists' release during his weekly audience in Rome.

According to unconfirmed reports, France has also dispatched Philippe Rondot, the secret agent who in the 1980s secured the release of hostages held in Lebanon, and a team of secret agents to Iraq to seek contacts with the captors.

The official Jordanian news agency, Petra, reported from Iraq last night that it expected the release of the journalists "within the next few hours", saying its report was based on "well-informed" sources.

However, there have been conflicting reports from the area over the past 24 hours with the Arab news network al-Arabiya reporting yesterday afternoon that their release was "imminent".

Al-Jazeera reported at the weekend that the original Sunday night deadline for their release had been extended by 24 hours.

But today there were claims that the deadline had actually been put forward by 48 hours, taking it to this evening.

A little-known militant group calling itself the Islamic Army in Iraq claimed responsibility for the hostage taking.

It did not say what would happen to the two men if France refused to back down, but it is thought to be the same group that claimed responsibility for the kidnapping and killing of the Italian journalist Enzo Baldoni.

In a videotape shown on Monday on al-Jazeera, Chesnot and Malbrunot called on Mr Chirac to obey the kidnappers' demand and rescind the ban on Muslim head scarves in schools to save their lives.

The controversial law is part of a broader measure aimed at combating racism that also bars skullcaps and crucifixes that will come into force when the school year restarts on Thursday.

Chesnot, 37, of Radio France Internationale, said: "It is a wrong and unjust law and we may die at any time."

Malbrunot, 41, who writes for Le Figaro and the regional daily newspaper Ouest France, said: "Our life is in danger and we might die at any moment if the law doesn't get banned."

Arnold Schwarzenegger delved deeply into his Hollywood past during his speech last night at the Republican national convention. While the man who is now governor of California has put his Hollywood career on the back-burner, his back catalogue still played a prominent role in his address to the party faithful.

Although focused on saluting the achievements of President Bush, Mr Schwarzenegger's speech came peppered with references to his own former career. After arriving on stage to prolonged applause, he told the delegates that the reception was "like winning an Oscar" (something he has never actually done). Later he reminded the convention that "one of my movies was called True Lies, and that's what the Democratic convention should have been called".

The choice of Mr Schwarzenegger as an early speaker at the RNC was widely interpreted as an attempt by the party to appeal to swing voters. The actor's views on such issues as abortion, gun control and gay marriage are markedly less right-wing than those of the bulk of Republican activists or, indeed, of the current President.

Nonetheless, Mr Schwarzenegger repeatedly praised Mr Bush for his "perseverance, character and leadership" in a speech which also made much of Mr Schwarzenegger's "rags to riches" story after arriving in America as an Austrian immigrant.

"Ladies and Gentlemen, America is back," he told a rapt convention in homage to his signature role as the Terminator.

The fate of two French journalists kidnapped in Iraq hangs in the balance as the deadline set by their kidnappers appeared to have been extended until this evening, according to reports.

But confusion remains as to whether the deadline set by Islamist militants expires tonight - 24 hours later than previously thought - or whether it has already run out.

The Arab League secretary general, Amr Moussa, and other officials said they believed the deadline was extended by 48 hours from Monday to Wednesday evening, not by 24 hours to Tuesday evening, as previously thought.

There has been no new word from the kidnappers of Georges Malbrunot and Christian Chesnot despite a huge diplomatic effort from France to free them.

"I think we can say the ultimatum has been delayed. That gives us some hope. It allows us to explore other channels," Lhaj Thami Breze, the president of the Union of French Islamic Organisations, told Europe 1 radio station. The Arab League's ambassador in Paris, Nassif Hitti, also said his organisation believed the deadline had not expired.

"That gives us more hope that there can perhaps be a positive outcome to this tragedy," he told LCI television.

An influential Sunni organisation in Iraq, the Committee of Ulema, said it had failed to get in touch with the kidnappers and feared the journalists would be killed.

"There are so many conflicting signals," said foreign ministry spokesman Herve Ladsous, who is travelling with the French foreign minister, Michel Barnier, on a diplomatic mission in the Middle East aimed at securing the journalists' release.

The gravity of Malbrunot and Chesnot's plight was highlighted yesterday when 12 Nepali hostages were executed by a different group of Iraqi militants.

French officials are remaining cautious about the journalists' fate.

"Today we have no information that allows us either to be inclined towards optimism or to fear the worst," the education minister, Francois Fillon, told RMC radio. A militant group calling itself the Islamic Army took Malbrunot and Chesnot hostage, demanding that France revoke a new law banning religious symbols in state schools, including the wearing of Muslim headscarves. The new school year starts on Thursday. But the French president, Jacques Chirac, has repeatedly rejected their demands.

Chesnot is a reporter for Radio France Internationale and Malbrunot writes for the dailies Le Figaro and Ouest France.

The Italian journalist, Enzo Baldoni, was killed last week after Italy refused demands to withdraw its troops from Iraq.

16 KILLED IN ISRAEL BUS BOMBINGS

Yesterday's two bus bombings in Israel were the first for six months - the tactic was familiar, and the scene horrifically so. "Three medics carefully took the body of a young woman through the empty window of a bus, her head tilted backward, long black hair covering her scorched face and neck," reports the Herald Tribune. "The two suicide bombers were also dead, the head of one lying on the bloody floor of bus No.6, next to a mound of human limbs, onions, grapes and shreds of clothing."

Sixteen people died and more than 100 were injured when the bombs detonated, around 100 metres apart, in Beersheba. More might have been killed had the driver of the number 12 bus not heard the explosion on the number six, opened the doors and urged people to disembark. Within seconds, his own bus blew up.

Hamas claimed responsibility, describing the bombings as a revenge attack for the assassination of its leaders Sheikh Ahmed Yassin and Abdel-Aziz al-Rantassi.

Israel has attributed the previous lull in violence to the construction of the West Bank security fence, which does not yet reach Beersheba. "For Israeli officials, the killings were proof of the vital necessity to accelerate the building programme," says Patrick Bishop in the Times. He quotes Tzahi Hanegbi, the public security minister, as saying: "What we have learned in the last six months ... is that in places where the fence exists there is no terror, and in places where there is no fence there is terror."

The Guardian says "construction of the barrier has been accompanied by other measures - mass arrests, restrictions on movements and assassination of militants - which may have been equally significant", adding that "during the last two years, virtually all the original leaders of Hamas in Gaza have been killed".

An Indian actor who found fame in Britain after landing a part in EastEnders has spoken for the first time about the immigration wrangle that could lead to his deportation, blaming poor legal advice and opposition from British Asian actors for his predicament.

Dalip Tahil is frustrated that the actors' union Equity has opposed his applications for a work permit in Britain, and says he wants to restore his credibility after being branded an illegal worker by the press.

Tahil, who is well known in India because of his prolific work in "Bollywood" cinema, came to Britain in 2002 to perform in the hit musical Bombay Dreams. He was picked by EastEnders' producers to play Dan Ferreira, the head of a new Indian family introduced to the soap last year.

But Equity complained that his work permit was not in order, and when the BBC applied to have it regularised, the union said the corporation had not done enough to make sure that there were no Asian actors already in Britain who could do the job. The BBC was forced to drop him from the soap, causing chaos as storylines were hastily rewritten.

Much of the subsequent press coverage was negative. The story was broken by the People last November, under the headline "Swoop on illegal EastEnd star - Dan banned from TV, he faces boot from Britain".

Tahil says he is the victim of the envy of some Asian actors who feel they should have got the part. "The Asian community has by and large supported me, and the majority of British Asian actors have been totally supportive," he said. "But I feel I wasn't given the support I would have expected from a union, a fraternity that I feel is my own. That was very disappointing."

Equity says it is obliged to protect the interests of its members, and there were a "multitude" of British Asian actors who could have played the part. A spokesman said: "This is not about Dalip Tahil's talents as an actor. Part of our job is to maximise the opportunities for our members."

Tahil faces deportation unless he can prove that his immigration status is the result of poor advice by his former solicitor, who is now the subject of a complaint to the Law Society. The actor has now engaged a new firm of lawyers and is hoping that the result of a forthcoming court hearing will allow him to resume his career in Britain.

"I would like to tell my supporters and wellwishers that I have been caught in circumstances not of my making," he told the Guardian. "I haven't come here to try to cheat the state. I'm here to contribute in any way I can. I have rented my own flat and I have never claimed benefits."

Tahil came to prominence after EastEnders decided it wanted to introduce an Indian family to Albert Square, feeling that the soap did not accurately reflect multicultural London. But the storyline was thrown into confusion when he was forced to leave, and his absence has been explained by increasingly far-fetched theories.

Tahil is no longer under contract to the BBC. A spokeswoman for EastEnders said it was open for him to return, but there were "no plans at present" to write him back in.

Before coming to Britain, Tahil was a prominent actor in India. He was educated at Sherwood College, an Indian public school, under an English principal, the Rev Robert Llewelyn, and says he regards Britain as a "home from home".

Asked why he does not simply return to India and resume his acting career there, the actor said: "I want to clear my reputation."

The al-Jazeera bureau in Baghdad is shut down for a month or maybe more, because, according to the Iraqi interior minister Falah al-Naqib, the network is encouraging "criminals and gangsters". Al-Jazeera claims that it is simply doing its job. So, does the Arab media's enfant terrible have anything helpful to offer, or is it inflammatory as charged?

For the last 10 months I have been studying al-Jazeera, visiting its bureaux around the world and interviewing its staff. On one level, it is obvious why the Americans and their Iraqi allies were keen to shut down the network's Baghdad bureau, especially in the run-up to a major assault on the holy city of Najaf. Al-Jazeera nearly bust up a much stronger American-led coalition before, in the winter of 2001, during the bombing of Afghanistan.

Then the network's monopoly on pictures from Taliban-controlled Afghanistan stretched the resolve of some of America's allies to breaking point. Pakistan's President Musharraf had to appeal to the US to stop the bombing before he lost control of his country. Violence against Christians broke out in Pakistan and police had to be stationed at churches, schools and hospitals.

A month ago, al-Jazeera's coverage of the kidnap of a Filipino truck driver rattled Philippine morale so much, President Gloria Arroyo was forced to pull her country's troops out of Iraq. If al-Jazeera had been there to report accidental damage to the Imam Ali mosque, all hell might have broken loose.

But what the US and the Iraqi authorities fail to take into account is that such reporting is only part of al-Jazeera's output. After 9/11, al-Jazeera started a weekly talkshow out of Washington, From Washington, during which the host interviewed many members of the US administration, as well as a variety of other politicians, Republican and Democrat.

In January, at the start of the US primary elections, al-Jazeera started another weekly show called US Presidential Race which, like From Washington, is broadcast from the Washington bureau. US Presidential Race is concerned with the forthcoming US elections: it covered most of the primaries in the major states and will continue to cover events up until the November elections and beyond, until the president's inauguration.

US Presidential Race has taken great pains to explain to Arab viewers the US political and electoral process. Al-Jazeera reporters travelled around America to meet Arab communities in different states; they asked people what they thought of the elections, what were the key issues, who they were going to vote for and why. By the time the election arrives, Arab viewers will have had an opportunity to follow the democratic process every step of the way.

More of the Democratic convention was aired on al-Jazeera than on most US networks - several hours each night, more than the combined time of the three US news networks covering the convention. Al-Jazeera's London bureau has a similar focus on British politics. Three weekly programmes come live out of London, besides which al-Jazeera gives extensive coverage to British news, politics, opposition activities and goings-on in parliament.

When the Iraqi Governing Council first banned al-Jazeera and al-Arabiya from covering any official activities in Iraq at the end of September 2003, the ban undermined the council's calls for democracy, and its stated independence from the US administration. Now the ban by the prime minister, Ayad Allawi, has similarly undermined his credibility.

Once again the Arab press has observed how life under this government, just like life under the coalition, is similar in spirit, if not in practice, to life under Saddam - journalists in the field are continually harassed, shot at and arrested and their equipment confiscated. Armed police forcibly closed down the al-Jazeera news bureaux while accusations that the channel had inside knowledge about attacks on the coalition are not substantiated with proof. Although this ban has not stopped the channel covering events inside Iraq, it has served to send a clear message to Iraqis - that freedom of expression in Iraq does not mean the same thing as it does in the west, just as civil rights for Arabs do not mean the same thing as they do in the west.

The ban has also done much to rehabilitate the station in the eyes of ordinary Arabs, who see the accusations against al-Jazeera as a mark of its independence. Hafez al-Mirazi, al-Jazeera's show host and bureau chief told me why when I spoke with him in Washington.

"The interviews we were given by the Americans, especially after the Afghan war, created some scepticism in the Arab world and drove people back to saying: 'There is something going on between those guys at al-Jazeera and the Americans. They are doing the jobs of Mossad and the CIA and the Israelis and the Americans.' Even the al-Qaida tapes, people were saying, were doctored and given to al-Jazeera in order to prove that 9/11 had been done by Arabs. The administration thinks that it is punishing us by not giving us interviews - in fact, they are not punishing us, but helping our image in the Arab world."

What the new government in Iraq should be doing is trying to engage with al-Jazeera, while tolerating the criticism that will inevitably come. That would send the message that they were serious about freedom of expression.

The Americans would do well to do the same. Unfortunately, despite a dramatic increase in the amount the US spends on public diplomacy programmes, to about $1.2bn a year, long-term investment in learning Russian during the cold war means today there is a serious dearth of Arabic speakers in the US administration. America has only two or three spokespeople capable of appearing in a debate on al-Jazeera to advocate US policy, in Arabic. And if America cannot even answer the case against it, then what can it expect but be trampled on in every argument? As Woody Allen once said, "90% of life is just showing up.".

Lord Black, according to the long-awaited internal report into the financial scandal at Hollinger International, was the architect of his own downfall.

"Black called the shots, and he wanted a board filled with prominent people who wouldn't make waves," it read. "Black got what he wanted, until he pushed so far beyond the limits of acceptable behaviour that he triggered the formation of the special committee and its investigative process."

The committee, led by former SEC chief Richard Breeden, paints a now familiar picture of Hollinger as a firm ruled by a tyrant who took what he wanted with scant regard for the business or other shareholders.

Lord Black and a handful of others are accused of looting the former Telegraph owner of more than $400m (£221m) through excessive compensation, unapproved bonuses, non-compete fees, loans and personal expenses.

Further allegations of his extravagance emerge in the 500-page document, as do further instances of extreme audacity.

When Lord Black was putting together the $2.1bn sale of Canadian publications to CanWest, he is said to have arranged a side deal for an annual $3.9m in ongoing "management fees" to be paid to his private firm Ravelston, in return for lowering the sale price by $39m.

In typically pompous fashion, he is cited elsewhere in the report writing to vice-chairman David Radler of the "splendid conveyance of the non-competition agreements from which you and I profited so well ..."

But shareholders are looking beyond titillating headlines. The report opens new avenues of questioning, related to the members of the audit committee, to Richard Perle, the only "independent" member of the executive committee, and to outside audit firm KPMG.

The special committee suggests the audit committee is partly to blame, despite Lord Black and Mr Radler keeping information from them. The report describes the committee as "careless" and "inert and ineffective" and refers to its "somnolence".

Their performance in reviewing non-compete payments to Lord Black and others "was unacceptable" and failed to question the $225m in management fees paid to Ravelston during the period in question.

"The board Black selected functioned more like a social club or public policy association than the board of a major corporation, enjoying extremely short meetings followed by a good lunch and discussion of world affairs." When one director questioned him, "Black hissed, 'this is my company'," the report said.

In one 65-minute meeting Lord Black and Mr Radler won approval for $38m in management fees to themselves, paid via Ravelston, an incentive plan for the firm's digital division worth $5.3m to the "senior executive group" and the sale for $1 of two newspapers to a firm controlled by the two men.

The report accused auditor KPMG of granting access to its papers very late in the inquiry. The auditors only allowed the investigators to review papers held by its Canadian arm, where Lord Black's holding companies are based. KPMG denied it obfuscated, noting the complexity of the inquiry.

More damning was the suggestion that KPMG failed to properly advise the audit committee. The report found KPMG, along with law firm Torys, failed to tell the audit committee whether certain management fees and non-compete clauses had violated financial standards. These failures partly justified the audit committee's apparent laxity over fees paid to Lord Black and his associates. They also went some way in absolving directors Henry Kissinger and Shmuel Meitar, who were not on the audit committee.

Only Richard Perle, a former US defence adviser closely associated with the Bush administration, was accused of enriching himself at the expense of the company. As the former chairman and chief executive of Hollinger Digital, Mr Perle received more than $3m in bonuses on top of his salary.

He breached his fiduciary duties by signing unanimous consents without reading the documents; several apparently authorised the controversial transactions. The report said he should return all money he earned while at the company.

Shareholder Tweedy Browne, which controls 18% of Hollinger and is also threatening legal action, said the report was a "step in the right direction". The fund manager's Laura Jereski said: "We still have a long way to go before the special committee completes its obligations to shareholders ... to secure large chunks of cash for the benefit of all shareholders. The responsibility for allowing the money to leave rests with the board."

Investigations are still going on at the SEC and the department of justice. There were suggestions the SEC had sent notices to former members of the company to the effect that it is preparing to file charges. The SEC made no comment.

Hollinger has filed a $1.25bn lawsuit naming Lord Black, Mr Radler and others; the sum is three times the $400m the firm claims was taken. That suit has been held up until publication of the report. Hollinger lawyers will now gain access to documents held by Ravelston, and the chance to depose Lord Black, Mr Radler and others who refused to give interviews during the internal inquiry.

Ravelston, representing Lord Black and Mr Radler, again asserted their innocence. "Mr Breeden and the special committee have squandered more than $25m of shareholders' money in a futile 14-month investigation that paralysed Hollinger International, eroded the value of its assets and persecuted and defamed those who created the value they are now vandalising," it said.

Hollinger has told the court it hopes to finish discovery by December; Lord Black's lawyers argue they need until next July. This most public of disputes still has far to go.

An old man comes to stay with his daughter and her family in The Clarinet Players (Twenty Minutes, 8.25pm, Radio 3). Before long he has left - feet first. His grandson, Michael, hears the undertakers cart away the body in the middle of the night, then witnesses the almost sinister funeral arrangements. He's sad about his grandad, of course, but excited about his inheritance. William Palmer's story is a bittersweet reminder of the self-absorption of youth.

The athletes have landed. At Gatwick. And all over the world. Men and women walking through their front doors again. Some covered in gold, others drenched in disappointment. Some met with hugs, others with, "What happened? You let yourself down, your family down, but most importantly, the entire nation down. Oh, well. I'll put the kettle on."

But one thing unites them all. Talent. Somewhere along the line, they proved they were brilliant enough to represent their country. After all, you can't just turn up to Athens with a rucksack and a pot of hummus and say, "Right. Think I fancy the hurdles today. Where do you want me? Great. See you tomorrow for a spot of javelin"

In contrast, I've just returned from the Edinburgh festival. And it's full of people who have simply pitched up and put a show on. "Right, think I fancy stand-up comedy today. Get me a mic. Great. See you tomorrow for Belgian dance/poetry." It doesn't even have to be good. Who's checking? I mean, you'll think it's good. Your mates say you're funny. But one man's comedy is another man's tragedy. And the trouble with the creative industries is that there's no quality control. Other fields have tricks to make entry harder. They're called exams. Wanna be a doctor? No trouble, Read this book. It's six years long. Barrister? Go to wig school. Comedian? Er ... just start I suppose.

I saw a lot of bad shows. It's heartbreaking. I know the difference between raw talent and no talent. But the latter often comes with self-delusion. A reality gap. How good we think we are versus what other people see. And it's that gap that I'm trying to reduce. My suggestion is as controversial as this: we should all try and find what we're good at. Which is often different to what we want to be good at. But chasing false dreams is ultimately the most crushing thing of all. You lose confidence, gain poverty.

I know all this. I'm a proper authority. Because I've done it. I went for gold but didn't realise they also made medals out of humble pie. But mine was even worse, stupider than anything I've described. I did take exams. I'm 32. I grew up in Thatcher's Britain. The City. Stockbroking everywhere on TV. I wanted a Porsche so fast it would melt. A shirt so stripey it would give me a headache. And a mobile phone the size of Kent (because I thought the bigger they were, the more expensive). All around me were stories of easy money. A mate's dad's plumber, who had a job fixing the toilets at Goldman Sachs one day and ended up becoming a millionaire just through eye-contact with the receptionist. Yes, please.

So I read Business at university. I did well. Excelled in marketing, psychology, strategy. Bombed in statistics, accountancy, financial markets. Not a problem. I'll just not take those options any more. All those numbers confuse me! And although you can already see what's coming, I couldn't. I wrote off to London. Basically, when do I start? Well, it didn't take long because one of the things they looked for was enthusiasm and passion. And boy, did I have those. I was able to look them in the eye, and say quite honestly, that this was all I ever wanted to do. Job offer accepted.

I loved the dealing room. I'd dreamed of it and it was even better than that. Screens. Shouting (increasingly at me). Quality banter with the boys. I was a bloke in a wheelchair, a novelty to them ... (my nickname was raspberry ripple - work it out). Many of them took me under their wing. I felt liked. And initially when I wasn't expected to do anything other than watch, I was good at my job. But after a few months, something terrible happened. They asked me to do stuff. Show some understanding. The job for which I was being paid. How dare they? And I tried to remember what I'd learned. Think Ash. Get a grip. Umm, er ... is it good when prices rise ... er, or is that sort of bad? Can't remember.

All I can say is, it's a proper horrible moment when your dreams come whacking down. There I was. In the place I'd always wanted to be, but with no right to be there. A constant headache - stress, not my shirt. Quite simply, crap at the job. And though the writing had been on the wall from long ago, it was not a wall I wanted to read. Because the reality of the situation, ie my shocking aptitude for maths (I once bought 10 million deutschmarks when I was supposed to sell them), was standing in the way of my dream. And I kidded myself and everyone around me for as long as I could. Until I was in the dealing/dreaming room, where suddenly there was nowhere to hide. But I wasn't fired. I didn't give them the chance.

I won't bore you with the lows that followed. Suffice to say, I felt a world-class tool. Lying is something you're supposed to do to other people. That's good lying. But to yourself? Unforgivable. Bad lying. But out of the gloom came a promise to myself. That I would chase a dream, but a realistic one based on an honest assessment of my abilities. I settled on television, and after a year out of work, fluked a job from which they haven't yet managed to fire me. I'm OK at it.

In a competitive world where even plenty of talented people fall by the wayside, non-talented people don't stand a chance. So find your thing. Even if it's totally random. On my way around Edinburgh, the street performers were sometimes better than the shows. You've probably seen the same ones at Covent Garden. Many opt to paint themselves silver or gold, and then either stand totally still for hours. Or perhaps move in a robotic fashion. It's easy to laugh at them. So I did. But actually, they were very good at it. They'd found their thing, bizarre though it was. So while I worry for their CVs ("2001-04. Painted myself gold and stood really still") I admire their skill. There was even someone who for £5 was offering to engrave your name on a grain of rice. Perhaps that's taking things too far, unless of course you want a risotto named after you.

Anybody who reads the poetry of Donald Justice, who has died aged 78, feels an urge to recite him to those in earshot; at each turn, new vistas open up. Justice won a Pulitzer Prize in 1980 and the Bollingen Prize in 1991. If rather less prolific than WH Auden, he, too, relished tinkering and a delight in all verse forms (with a particular liking for the sestina) and what unifies his poetry is a distinct, if self-effacing, authorial voice. In discussing the relationship between memory and metre, he remarked that "one motive for much, if not all, art is ... to keep memorable what deserves to be remembered".

An accomplished painter, he had also studied music but lacked the confidence to pursue it as a career. Such wide-ranging references inform without encumbering his poetry - which also draws inspiration from popular thrillers. All of which made him a more inspired teacher and critic than many other poets who, like him, fetch up in academia. His poems were rarely longer than a page, and there was no great bulk in his total output.

Justice was an only child, born in Miami and the son of an itinerant carpenter. Despite the grind of the Depression among the near-poor like his parents, he had piano lessons. Of his women teachers he recalled: "It was clear to everyone, themselves included, that they were dedicated less to teaching than to the small sums their teaching brought in. This obvious fact embarrassed no one. Times were hard and these things were understood."

However, one teacher, Mrs Snow, was a serious musician with a rhythm band. She made pupils write down the Baconian motto "writing makes the exact man", a harbinger of the precision for which Justice was renowned.

After Allapattah elementary school - from which the bone disease osteomyelitis kept him away a year - and Andrew Jackson high school, he left Miami high to go to its City University in 1942. He had already read a great deal, and begun to write. There, too, he studied music with composer Carl Ruggles, but, when he graduated in 1945, it was with a degree in English.

The childhood illness had kept him from war service, and he moved to New York, subsisting on odd jobs which gave him a taste of the quintessential Greenwich Village life. But in 1947, he opted for a master's course at the University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill, there meeting another writer, Jean Ross, whom he soon married.

After an unsatisfactory doctoral spell at Stanford University, California, they went to back to Florida, where he was, for a time, an instructor at the University of Miami. Crisscrossing America, the couple met encouraging writers - his wife's brother-in-law was Peter Taylor - including Randall Jarrell and Robert Frost. Then, from 1952 to 1954, he did a doctorate at the University of Iowa's programme in creative writing, the Iowa Writers' Workshop. This brought him into contact and conversations with John Berryman, Robert Lowell and the under-rated Karl Shapiro, as well as Nelson Algren, whose gambling habits were more outlandish than his own penchant for a flutter.

A 1954 Rockefeller award brought Justice a year's sojourn in Europe, a stimulus to his writing - he was to be an adept translator. He was soon to return to the Workshop and remain there until 1967.

In 1960, he published a first collection of poems, The Summer Anniversaries - a pamphlet, a chapbook, The Old Bachelor, had appeared in 1951. That 1960 collection contained On The Death Of Friends In Childhood, which was to figure in his former pupil John Irving's The Hotel New Hampshire - and in the movie made of it.

In 1967, a second collection, Night Light was published - and Justice moved to Syracuse University, where he stayed until 1970. He then spent a year at the University of California, Irvine, and another year at Iowa. In 1973, his Departures was nominated for the National Book Award. In 1979 came his Pulitzer prize-winning Se lected Poems. From 1982 to 1992, he was at the University of Florida, Gainesville, after which he retired to Iowa City. In 1987 The Sunset Maker was published.

Interspersed with all these works were pamphlets, selections, and revisions of individual volumes. Justice also tried to write plays and adaptations but, to his chagrin, found that something eluded him in doing so.

His mid-career taste was for chance assembly: one poem adapts prose by Henry James, another springs from a phrase in Wallace Stevens's notebook,"the alp at the end of the street", and another simply quotes a line from a spy novel - in so doing, it makes demotic dialogue almost transcendental: "Maybe you know Bliss by another name." If, at times, a sense of loss pervades the work:

I saw my grandmother grow weak.
When she died, I kissed her cheek.
I remember the new taste -
Powder mixed with a drying paste

there is, as with Philip Larkin, also a relish of life.

Justice could well be a poet who outpaces those of his contemporaries whose packaging has begun to fall away. Many now quote, or anthologise, Ode To A Dressmaker's Dummy (1967), or the figure of Death whose arrival is the Incident In A Rose Garden (1967), while, more recently, there was Ralph: A Love Story (1999), a poignantly rollicking tale of a cinema projectionist who uses his cubby-hole to cuddle, and impregnate, the owner's daughter; shipped out by the navy, he heard later what had happened, but:

So it was gone, the way a thing will go
Yet keep a sort of phantom presence always.
He might be drinking with some woman, lying
Beside her on a tourist cabin bed,
When something would come ghosting back to him,
some little thing. Such paradise it had been!

And, at the end, nightwatchman Ralph indeed - surrounded by cheap thrillers - finds it all come back, in a narrow bed at his sister's:

in the form
Of images in the dark, shifting and flashing,
Badly projected, spooling out crazily
In darkness, in a little room, and he
Could not control it. It was like dying.
No, it was dying, and he let it go.

"Donald Justice is dead" is itself a sentence from his poem Variations On A Text By Vallejo (1973). This opens "I will die in Miami in the sun" and ends by picturing the scene as, one Sunday, the sun comes out, shining on the bay, on the white buildings while cars move slowly along, "headlights on in spite of the sun". And so it is that:

after a while the diggers with their shovels
Walked back to the graveside through the sunlight,
And one of them put his blade into the earth
To lift a few clods of earth, the black marl of Miami,
And scattered the dirt, and spat,
Turning away abruptly, out of respect.

Justice would have greeted wryly that, come the event, it was in Iowa City, on a Friday, when he died, and that death made definitive the publication later last month of his Collected Poems.

Justice is survived by his wife and his son.

· Donald Justice, poet, critic and teacher, born August 12 1925; died August 6 2004

When the season kicked off, just three weeks ago, Sunderland were many people's tip for automatic promotion. Now they look a busted flush.

Nicky Forster's second-minute header proved to be the difference as Sunderland slumped to their third straight away defeat.

There was plenty of huff and puff from Mick McCarthy's side, but not much quality as Reading clung on for victory.

Reading went ahead after just two minutes. The goal was as straightforward as they come, Andy Hughes' right-wing cross brushing off Forster's head and past the out-of-position Mart Poom.

It took 10 minutes or so for Sunderland to regroup, and another five for them to launch a meaningful attack. John Oster made space down the right and found Kevin Kyle, who launched himself at the ball - arms outstretched like Superman - only to balloon his header over the bar.

Kyle then turned provider minutes later, flicking on Gary Breen's long thump forward into Dean Whitehead's path. The midfielder only had Marcus Hahnemann to beat but, after having elected to shoot early, saw his effort skim the outside of the post.

The rest of the first-half was largely forgettable, with both sides cancelling each other out. The half-chances, however, fell to Reading. On the half-hour, James Harper's free-kick bounced off Poom's chest and squirmed inches out of the oncoming Forster's reach.

Then, just before the interval, Forster had a better chance to increase the lead when sent clear by Dave Kitson. But he overran the ball and allowed Poom to gather.

McCarthy brought on three substitutes shortly after half-time, but it was Reading who continued to look the more dangerous. As the game opened up, they increasingly tested Sunderland's back four, only to lose composure in the final third. Again it was Forster who was the main culprit, shooting straight at Poom after being put through by Kitson's fine backheel.

Reading went even closer moments later. From a corner, Steve Sidwell's header hit the post but Kitson, following up, could not capitalise.

Sunderland looked dangerous on the break, and Elliot should have done better when he rounded Hahnemann, only to fire into the side-netting.

"Laughable," said the Bath rugby coach John Connolly. "Ridiculous" was the view of the former England football assistant manager John Gorman. The idea that England's most successful rugby coach might take charge of one of the country's leading football clubs is not one that many leading coaches are taking seriously.

"I think it is someone with their ego out of control," said Connolly. "Sometimes coaches get carried away with their own success and that has been proven in many cases. If you are going to manage or coach a side in a sport then you need an in-depth knowledge of the game. You have got to know what you are talking about."

Jose Mourinho's and Arsène Wenger's success supports the theory that the best managers are not necessarily the finest footballers. Both those coaches are highly respected, chiefly because of their managerial achievements and tactical acumen but also for their ability to extract the best from players. Woodward can certainly motivate, but can he transfer the qualities that have produced success on the rugby field to the football pitch? Connolly is not convinced.

"There are certain management and organisational skills in elite sport which are similar but not the same. What is required in rugby and football is physically and mentally different. The games are totally different; for example there is a certain calmness in soccer whereas rugby is played at a high arousal level."

Tom McNab has practical experience of crossing sporting boundaries. The former Great Britain athletics coach has worked with Chelsea and the England rugby team as a fitness expert, but it is his time with the British bobsleigh team during the 1980s which carries the greatest resonance to Woodward's situation.

"The technical jump is too big to transfer sports," he said. "When I moved across from athletics to bobsleigh I was applying myself to the things I knew already. The driving of the bobsleigh would be the equivalent of the football match, but I didn't look at bobsleigh in terms of the driving, just the push start, and I only looked at the fitness side of rugby. I was only operating in the areas which were reasonably clear."

There is little doubt that Woodward has a passion for football, but professional footballers expect a more technical perspective. However, Frank Clark, deputy chief executive of the League Managers' Association, believes that it would be possible for Woodward to accumulate the knowledge required.

"We are always happy to accept talented people in the industry and he has obviously got some terrific qualities in terms of organisational and motivational skills," said Clark. "But if he wants to be a head coach or a team manager then we would expect him to go through all the qualifications."

Those regulations apply in the Premiership, where a head coach or manager must be in possession of a Uefa Pro licence. But the Football League does not set the same standards, opening the possibility of Woodward taking over at a club in the lower divisions. A more plausible scenario is that he might be given a broader remit which takes advantage of his ability to organise and delegate.

Woodward applied those skills to the England rugby team, where teams of coaches were designated to look after forward and back play, kicking and throwing. Though such methods were seen as revolutionary in rugby, they would not be breaking new ground in football. "It's all been done before," said Gorman. "For example Ian Rush was working with the strikers at Liverpool last year, and most clubs have had a coach that works on the defensive play and another coach that works with the forwards for some time."

Another quality synonymous with Woodward is his attention to detail. ProZone, which monitors the movement of players during matches, was heralded as a huge advance when first utilised by the England rugby team, but football already used it. All of which suggests that the man who revolutionised English rugby must bring something different to the table if he is to be embraced by football.

Lecturers at London Metropolitan University, one of the largest in the UK, will today demonstrate against contracts which unions claim compromise academic freedom and threaten the jobs of almost 400 staff directly involved.

Yesterday the university's vice chancellor, Brian Roper, accused the lecturers of living in "la-la land" in claiming that the jobs would be lost.

The dispute marks a new low in relations at the university, created by the merger of two parent institutions two years ago, and the largest single academic body in London.

Managers say lecturers from one merger partner, London Guildhall University, must today move on to contracts identical to those of staff of North London University, the other partner. If not, they will be deemed to have left their jobs, the university says.

However, their union, Natfhe, refuses to accept the shift, claiming the contracts have been unilaterally imposed and limit professional autonomy. Lecturers will today burn copies of the contract outside university buildings. They say its terms require them to be in their offices from nine to five, affecting their research freedom, and to answer to "line managers" for teaching.

The university says it has offered unions every opportunity to discuss the deal, and denies that jobs will be lost in the changeover provided staff accept the contracts.

With Natfhe insisting that staff returning for the new term are not working on the contracts, and the university stating that employees will be deemed to have accepted the deal simply by turning up, the dispute has entered a legal thicket in which both sides claim to have employment law on their side.

While union leaders say they will do their best to avoid any impact on students, there are threats of one-day strikes during induction week and beyond.

Greg Barnett, Natfhe chairman at the university, said last night: "We as a union don't accept that transfer [to a new contract]." Its terms included "nothing about professional autonomy and discretion". Amanda Sackur, another Natfhe representative, accused the university of wanting to adopt a "bullies' charter" that others might emulate.

Dr Roper rejected the claim that the university would dismiss the 387 academics affected. "It is a kind of la-la land," he said last night. "Tomorrow will dawn, and life will go on." It was "rubbish" that academic independence would be threatened; the deal had been accepted by Natfhe under a national agreement in 1999, and it did not affect pay or leave.

The university also rejects suggestions that it has jeopardised the quality of its degrees this year in the face of a boycott by some external validators sympathetic to the lecturers. Natfhe says the process has been compromised because the examiners were told they would be judged to have approved scripts if the university did not hear from them by August 28.

Dr Roper accused the union of "guerrilla tactics", and insisted that all degrees would be validated as normal after the university recruited extra external examiners, with the process complete by September 8.

The education watchdog Ofsted yesterday urged parents to be its "eyes and ears" in nurseries and childminders' homes as it published figures showing it received one complaint for every 20 registered care providers last year.

The statistics reveal Ofsted, which took over responsibility for regulating early years childcare from local authorities in 2002, investigated 6,250 complaints in the year to last March. Of those, it took legal action in 378 cases, including four prosecutions, shutting 49 nurseries and childminders and suspending 122 more. Three emergency orders were issued after concerns that a child was suffering from or at risk of serious harm.

Complaints included a childminder seen dragging a three-year-old child along the street so forcefully he was pulled from the ground, and a nursery with a leaking roof and mould on the walls.

The chief inspector of schools, David Bell, launching Ofsted's second annual report on early years inspections in England, said most childcare providers provided good or satisfactory care, with only 1% failing to meet minimum government standards between April 2003 and June this year.

There are 84,000 childminders and 34,000 nurseries in England, providing places for 1.4 million pre-school children.

However, Mr Bell acknowledged inspectors were not able to monitor nurseries and childminders "24 hours a day", and urged parents to "act as Ofsted's eyes and ears" and contact inspectors with particular concerns.

The report, Protection through regulation, is published weeks after a BBC documentary used secret filming to expose bad practice in three private nurseries. Of those, two have now been ordered to make improvements within a set time or face being struck off.

Ofsted insists it was already moving to address one of the key issues raised by the programme, the advance notice period given to providers before inspection which is to be shortened from weeks to days.

Yesterday's report is designed to reassure parents that, while complaints over childcare remain relatively few, Ofsted acts swiftly and effectively to address concerns.

The government, too, is anxious to be seen to be ensuring high standards in childcare, amid moves rapidly to expand the sector. Critics argue it is difficult to reconcile quantity with quality, when childcare is still a low-paid, low status occupation with patchy training.

Ofsted rated 43.3% of childminders as good and 56% as satisfactory - meaning they met all 14 national childcare standards. Of the nurseries, 51.3% were rated good and 47.6% satisfactory.

Only 0.7% of childminders and 1.1% of nurseries were deemed unsatisfactory.

The proportion of complaints is around the same as in Ofsted's last report, which covered 19 months up to March 2003. Most concerns were raised by parents or other relatives of children cared for, followed by anonymous sources, social services, nursery staff and Ofsted staff or inspectors.

Childcare bodies welcomed the report, and urged parents to use inspection information when choosing childcare.

Daycare Trust's director, Stephen Burke, said: "It is essential that Ofsted continues to develop and creates a transparent inspection process where standards are clearly understood by childcare providers and parents alike.

"We need to move towards a situation where parents are automatically given at least a summary of the Ofsted report when inquiring about a childcare place with a provider."

Horror stories from the inspectors

Complaints to Ofsted last year (real cases with identifying details changed)

· A childminder refused to ban her son, who was being investigated for alleged abuse of his own child, from her home while she was minding children. Ofsted was granted an emergency legal order adding a new condition to her registration, meaning that her son must never be present while she was looking after children. Ofsted carried out unannounced inspections to ensure she complied

· Another childminder lost her registration after admitting leaving her own child and a child in her care unsupervised, saying that it was acceptable to do so because a neighbour could listen to them on a baby monitor

· During an unannounced inspection, a creche in a large leisure centre was found to be held in a dirty, unventilated room with broken lights, unsuitable furniture and toilets blocked and flooded with sewage. Toddlers were bored, lacked toys and "wandered aimlessly, quarrelling". Inspectors gave the nursery a week to improve or face prosecution. It improved, and inspectors made more unannounced visits to check standards

· A nursery refused to reduce the number of children on its roll, despite undergoing major building work which placed youngsters at risk of harm. Ofsted won a legal order compelling the nursery to cut the number of children in its care and to keep some rooms off limits in order to retain its official registration. Inspectors checked to ensure the new conditions were being followed

The 91-year-old patient was given more than half a page in yesterday's Daily Telegraph to describe his one-month stay in an NHS hospital. He had private health insurance but with two fractures to his leg he "instinctively sought the reassurance offered by the big William Harvey hospital in Kent with its wide range of skills and equipment". This was no ordinary nonagenarian but Bill Deedes, Harold Macmillan's cabinet minister for spin, decorated war hero, golf partner to Denis Thatcher, former Daily Telegraph editor and still an outstanding regular contributor from various war zones.

He suffered some familiar problems: visitors to other patients talking too loudly in a ward of ill people in pain; an uncomfortable trolley wait when his electrically powered, air-mattressed bed, disconnected from the power supply and kept waiting outside x-ray for too long, let its powerless mattress subside so that the frame bit into his back. Negligence? "No, the pressure on the x-ray department was simply too heavy - in August, as everywhere else, staff are away..." Far from being yet another long indictment of the shortcomings of the NHS, the Deedes report was a hymn of praise for the help he received from the NHS. Both nurses ("a seam of gold") and physiotherapists (artists who "are the spring that restores so many patients back to normality") are singled out for detailed praise. His aim was to correct the imbalance of other anecdotal stories that have left "a dark portrait of our hospitals". He concluded: "If we are not to lose perspective, we ought to be more aware of, and more grateful than we are for, this golden thread of selfless service."

Bill Deedes is not a lone voice. Successive annual surveys of up to 400,000 NHS patients have shown similar high approval rates (75% "excellent" or "very good" and 92% ready to recommend the hospital they used to a friend). Of course there are still problems: too little involvement of patients in treatment; too little information on the side-effects of medicines; a shortfall in pain control. But the NHS is not in as dire a state as Telegraph leader writers usually assume.

As progress is made in reducing premature deaths from the major killers, such as cancers and heart disease, healthcare systems worldwide are turning their attention to improving the quality of care for people with long-term conditions such as arthritis and diabetes.

The NHS Improvement Plan, published in June, includes a specific commitment to support people with long-term conditions to live healthy lives. This is welcome recognition of the need to reposition the NHS from the treatment of life-threatening illness to the continuing care of people whose conditions cannot be cured.

Four things now need to happen to turn this commitment into reality. First, the Department of Health (DoH) must show the same determination in improving the quality of care for people with long-term conditions as they have in reducing waiting times for treatment.

The political logic here is as inescapable as the medical logic. There are around 17 million people living with long-term conditions and these people have a strong interest in receiving the best possible care. A government that delivers tangible improvements in care will bolster its own support as well as doing the right thing for the population.

The difficulty will be to ensure that inertia within the NHS and other demands do not crowd out the commitment to give higher priority to long-term conditions. Learning from the success in reducing waiting times, the government must ensure that this policy is properly resourced, and is communicated to the NHS as a key objective in the next phase. There also needs to be a high-powered team of clinicians and managers leading implementation and delivery.

Second, within the NHS, primary care trusts (PCTs) must confound their critics who argue that they are the poor relations of the NHS family. As the organisations that control most of the NHS budget, PCTs are well placed to ensure that patients with long-term conditions have access to the care they need.

PCTs must use the new contract for GPs to reward high-quality primary care, and to arrange for the provision of extra services in the community. These services include those of the "community matrons" who will take responsibility for people who are most at risk because they have more than one long-term condition.

Third, the contribution of social care in enabling people with long-term conditions to live healthy lives must be recognised. This will not be easy in view of the modest increase in funding for social care announced in the July spending review, and the limited political salience of social care within government.

The key priority here is to encourage closer integration of health and social care at a local level, making use of the flexibilities that are available to local authorities and PCTs. This includes further extending direct payments to empower users to access the services they need, and using the single assessment process to ensure that frontline staff are working in a coordinated way.

Fourth, the NHS needs to work with the DoH to change policies that are inconsistent with the emphasis on long-term conditions. The greatest risks relate to the establishment of NHS foundation trusts centred on acute hospitals only, and the new system of "payment by results" under which hospitals will be paid for every patient they treat according to a national tariff.

Healthcare systems that have made most progress in responding to the challenge of long-term conditions place a strong emphasis on service integration. NHS foundation trusts that bring together hospital and community services, either in the same organisation or through integrated working, offer the best chance of achieving similar improvements in the NHS.

Even more important, the policy under which hospitals are paid for every patient they treat needs to be complemented by incentives that support high-quality primary care, and avoid unnecessary hospital admissions. The new contract for GPs should help in strengthening primary care, and action is urgently needed to modify payment by results to prevent people being treated in hospital when better alternatives are available.

PCTs again have a role in offering incentives to GPs to help patients remain in the community. For its part, the DoH must ensure that the tariff does not encourage increases in emergency admissions of people with long-term conditions, and does not reward re-admissions to hospital within, say, 28 days of patients being discharged. These risks are recognised by the department, although it is not clear how they will be managed.

A combination of healthcare organisations that integrate services and an incentive system that supports the direction set out in the improvement plan is needed to support the government's aspiration to reposition the NHS towards the care of people with long-term conditions.

· Chris Ham is professor of health policy and management at the Health Services Management Centre, University of Birmingham, and until June was director of the strategy unit in the DoH. The fifth edition of his book, Health Policy in Britain, has just been published by Palgrave.

Recently, quite out of the blue, Anthony Douglas had a phone call from a woman who introduced herself as the widow of his natural father. Douglas had never met her - indeed, he had met his father only once, fleetingly, 25 years ago - but she had belatedly discovered his existence and told him he had four half-brothers who were keen to make his acquaintance.

"So here I am, at 55, inheriting potentially another set of relationships in this kind of complex web," says Douglas, who was adopted at birth. "At my age, you are a bit wary of it, but for them, of course, it's new and exciting. And it is for me in many ways: it's the last piece of information about it, but it's taken 55 years to complete all the pieces of the jigsaw."

This complexity of Douglas's background enables him, he feels, to empathise with the fractured structures of so many modern families. It has set him in good stead during a successful career in social work and is likely to prove even more relevant in his new and highly challenging role, which he starts today, as chief executive of the Children and Family Court Advisory Support Service, better known as Cafcass.

As well as empathy, his experience of adoption - by no means an unqualified success, on his assessment - has no doubt contributed to a passion for helping families in crisis and, above all, children in need. "It's highly emotive work," he says, admitting to being something of a driven character. "I don't see how you can manage it neutrally. It's not like manufacturing kitchen units."

Douglas is sure to need every drop of that passion in the weeks and months ahead. Cafcass, set up in 2001 to coordinate representation of children's interests before the courts, had what he calls a "disastrous" first two years. He thinks that its performance since then has been somewhat better, and that the organisation has not had sufficient credit for that, but that it still needs to undergo a process of cultural change in key parts of its operation.

Following radical intervention by ministers, Cafcass has been moved under the umbrella of the Department for Education and Skills. The arms-length body has been given a more realistic budget of £107m - up almost 13% - and a new board chaired by Lady Pitkeathley, the Labour peer who is seen as having a wise head and a safe pair of hands.

Douglas, who was headhunted for the job from Suffolk county council, where he had spent less than two years as director of social care and health, has never previously worked with Pitkeathley, but he recognises a kindred spirit. "She wants to be associated with success, not failure, and wants to develop a stronger culture of delivery, urgency and corporate ownership of Cafcass," he says. "We both believe in a supportive management culture for frontline staff, but equally we are both determined to get the work done without any nonsense."

Whichever way you look at it, there was a good deal of nonsense in Cafcass's early years. Douglas, who was closely monitoring developments from a standpoint of chair of the British Association for Adoption and Fostering, believes that the management process became widely discredited. This led to creation of parallel managements, most damagingly among the guardians ad litem appointed by courts to represent children.

"Many staff don't say 'we' as much as 'Cafcass', as if it's an external or independent organisation," he observes. "What I want to get to very quickly is a 'Team Cafcass' approach, where all of our staff, whether employed or self-employed [as many guardians are], think of it as their organisation that they are proud to be part of and are positive about."

As an avid cricketer, Douglas is keen also that his team should play to its strengths. That means a switch, in line with the recent green paper on parental separation, from what he terms "commentating" to more short-term intervention - "sorting" - in stressed families. That, in turn, implies a shift of emphasis from public law cases, typically involving children being taken into care, to private child custody issues.

But how can that be achieved without leaving gaps on the public side?

Douglas is convinced there is much duplication of effort by Cafcass staff and local authority social workers, assessing and working on behalf of the same child. Even before he took up his post, he was holding preliminary discussions with local government groups about sharing resources through formal compacts.

"There's a long-held principle of tandem representation, and the independence of the guardian is, of course, sacrosanct in law," he says. "But a lot of time is sometimes spent duplicating a good local authority assessment rather than perhaps using a different validation process and spending time on those cases - which I guess would be more private law cases - where active intervention would really help change children's lives.

"It's like anything in life: if you have got an excellent piece of work, an excellent piece of plumbing, say, you don't get a second plumber to come along and rip it apart and do it again."

As a notably thoughtful care professional - he is currently writing his fourth book - Douglas reflects on two epiphanies along the route of his career. The first came as a social services team manager in the 1980s, when he realised that his staff-centred view of the world was wrong and that his focus should be on outcomes for users of the services. The second came at Suffolk, where he learned the critical distinction between leadership and management and the importance of the former. Symbolically, he had no office of his own at county hall.

At Cafcass, he intends generally to lead rather than manage, but has identified a couple of management tasks: implementing a 10-year pay and workforce strategy, which will include incentives to ensure that more experienced staff focus on more complex cases; and pushing through changes to create what he calls "Cafcass local" and "Cafcass direct", delivering services readily accessible to people who need short-term help and intervention. "That implies a step change, from what is primarily a care management service to a faster, flexible front-end service," he says.

Expect, too, that Cafcass will become a much more transparent organisation. Before he settled to social work, Douglas dabbled in journalism, and his policy has always been one of openness to the media. He is already in talks with an independent television producer about filming some early intervention work.

He is in no doubt that the approach of "certain newspapers" contributes to the poor image of social work in Britain - an image that he says astonishes overseas staff he has recruited to Suffolk. But he insists: "My job, and that of other leaders of the profession, is to treat that as a fact of life and to get as much publicity about the positive work that's done, nine times out of 10, as about the mistakes and catastrophes that do happen."

Douglas thinks it will take two or three years to get Cafcass back on track to becoming a world-class service. Despite marked improvement in its performance, there continue to be cases of children waiting to be allocated guardians - particularly in regional "hot spots" - and the organisation is on average allocating 56% of public law cases within two days of request, against a target of 70% by March next year. On the private law side, 4.4% of reports are unallocated less than 10 weeks before the due date for filing with the court, against a current target of 4.0%.

By the very nature of its work, Douglas reckons it will always be an uphill task for Cafcass to achieve a glowing reputation. When people come into contact with it, they tend to be in conflict and are angry and distressed - as exemplifed recently by high-profile protests by campaigners for fathers' rights.

Douglas will aim to reach out even to "hostile" groups, though Cafcass has a standing policy of no contact with the most militant, Fathers 4 Justice. But he believes firmly in listening to the child when it comes to decisions about custody and access. "Children as young as three, four or five who experience parental separation will usually know who they want to be with," he says. "If you follow their instincts, that's normally the best way to do it."

Sunday, 9am. With a dull thud, a wodge of newspapers drops on the mat and once a week, in some household, hearts drop with them. A paedophile outed, a minister exposed, a council's competence trashed ... shock, horror, scandal and huge headlines.

Of course, the News of the World and its like are not some force of nature. They answer to the courts and, very occasionally, the non-statutory Press Complaints Commission. But because they get to strike first, lasting damage can be done long before retractions are made or cases alleging invasion of privacy (surprisingly few so far under the Human Rights Act) come to court. The tabloids' sense of political invulnerability was shown by this summer's treatment of the home secretary, David Blunkett; the only "public interest" in putting his private life on display is prurience, coupled with twisted attitudes towards disability.

Public bodies are increasingly aware, as Sue Stapely puts it, that "the legal process often trails along well after reputation has been assassinated by the media". Stapely is one of a specialist breed of public relations consultants, the crisis manager. She is a solicitor who, as head of public affairs at the Law Society when it was undergoing revolts and bloody convulsions, learned about reputation damage the hard way.

Her message to health trusts, social services departments and so on is to plan and prepare: "Don't give the press an unchallenged run". Professionals in the public sector are more media savvy than ever, she notes, yet she and her colleagues still get calls from senior managers the day the first adverse report appears, on the eve of a hearing or, worse, the day after the first press coverage of the vexing issue appears. They only ask for support when it becomes clear that their council is not being sympathetically reported. When private firms see the proverbial hit the fan, the need to work on public relations is quickly grasped.

Reputation is an asset; in Othello, Shakespeare called it the immortal part. It is worth money and comprehensive performance assessment ranking. Reputation management is now firmly established on the business school curriculum, but it is only recently that public managers have started spending with firms that claim to sustain or turn around the way organisations are perceived - the lottery company Camelot's redemption is hailed as a successful makeover. Kingston upon Hull and the London borough of Hackney are striving to find the formula.

Crisis management is something else and, Stapely says, should not be needed if organisations conducted regular and rigorous "bear trap audits" to identify which of their activities and staff (or elected members) might be vulnerable to media attention or precipitate a crisis.

"Few organisations have fireproof systems in place to manage their reputations in the event of crisis," Stapely says. "Many strive to assess risks but leave open how they are perceived by the public - the senior manager found downloading child pornography; a claim of sexual discrimination or harassment; a local authority held liable for child abuse by one of its employees; a school sliding down the league tables; a public body facing an allegation of fraud, extravagance or financial impropriety; a tribunal case alleging wrongful dismissal."

She is no great fan of in-house public sector PR, talking of "small armies of communications professionals" who think they can handle media interest unaided. Some believe you cannot sup with the devil and that the best response to media assault is silence or escape. No, she says: brief the journalists, talk them through it, respond to their calls, be available day and night.

She recommends preparing summaries of issues in dispute if there is a court or tribunal case. Journalists love a good summary; give them a brief description of the organisation and a cast list of witnesses and protagonists. "These tools are seized upon gratefully by journalists and immediately demonstrate the confident, accessible approach of the organisation," she says.

"When Newcastle city council found itself facing a major defamation suit, involving former employees who had been accused of abusing small children in their care, its new chief executive brought in reputation management advisers early, was courageous in taking full responsibility, admitting that the matter had not been handled well in the past, and convening a press conference immediately after judgment had been given and dealing candidly with all inquiries."

He and the council had to live through 48 hours of bruising press exposure, but eventually it was recognised, Stapely says, that "the authority had acted well and honourably in the most difficult circumstances".

Only professional jeremiahs of overpopulation, such as Crispin Tickell and Jonathan Porritt, noticed the forecast last week that Britain would have 4 million extra people by 2025, plus a further 1.5 million by 2050 - a 10% rise in the lifetime of our children. The UK is the only major European population still growing.

Public debate on population is so preoccupied with the social impact of immigration that nobody asks how we will support 66 million consumers of energy, housing and driving space on the roads. Already we have 631 people per square mile in the UK (993 in England) - more than twice as many as France, and the highest density in Europe after the Netherlands. China's population density is 352.

Yet the new forecast from the US-based Population Reference Bureau attracted no comment from our government, which has barely begun to shape a population policy, as distinct from an immigration policy, which it says sets "no upper limits".

Tickell and Porritt are patrons of the Optimum Population Trust (OPT), which takes a deeper look at the issue. It argues that the government's hopes for sustainable development in food, clean water, healthy soil and a stable climate will be dashed if the population is not reduced from 60 million to 52.5 million by 2050, and possibly to 30 million by 2121.

The OPT demands firm action against unintended pregnancies, particularly among teenagers, and extra support for the raising of small families. The average British woman chooses to have 1.7 children; in Italy and Spain it is 1.2.

Unabashed at sharing some opinions with the British National Party, the UK Independence Party and the Daily Mail, the OPT wants net immigration brought down to zero. Immigration has been the main contributor to recent UK population growth and is projected to account for more than 80% of future growth.

Two years ago, 360,000 people left the UK and 513,000 came in - a net immigration of 153,000. The government expects the influx to be lower when the figures for 2003 are released, but natural increase - the excess of births over deaths - is expected to rise from 62,500 in 2002 to 83,000.

The OPT has been a voice in the wilderness, but in recent weeks officials have begun replying to its emails and even inviting its input on the future of farming. Tickell, who is director of Oxford's Green College environmental policy centre, does not support OPT's ambition to reduce net immigration to zero, but he does want to stem the flow by discouraging migrants and refugees from coming to Europe. He argues: "We should give aid at the European level to the countries where refugees originate - especially aid in population policies."

Porritt agrees that most of the expected increase will be caused by immigration, "plus a bit of demographic pressure". But, unlike the OPT, he accepts the government's current immigration policy for humanitarian reasons and because immigrants will help the economy. "I don't think they're letting too many people in," he says. "Population talk is far too tied up with immigration and racism. The fact is that we are nearly in balance. We're not showing hundreds of thousands coming in."

Porritt, who drafted the Ecology party's demographic policy in 1976, can claim to be the doyen of the population prophets. Now, as chairman of the Sustainable Development Commission, he is an influential critic who blames the government for not having a population policy.

"The next sustainable development strategy paper is due in March, but will population even feature in it? This government is not doing enough to make a difference. We need more energetic policies on fertility management, which could give us a net reduction even with the present rate of immigration. People should be made to understand that their commitment to the world includes not having too many children."

The OPT appears relatively untroubled that its two famous patrons disagree with its aim to stop immigration in its tracks. The trust's starkest warnings come from its research coordinator, Andrew Ferguson, a retired airline pilot who calculates that Britain will only be sustainable when its population is brought down to 20 million or, at most, 30 million. "Only by extravagant use of fossil fuel can we support 60 million people, let alone 65 million," Ferguson says. "As we run out, we will have to go back to old methods of making energy, and that will need lots more space - wood burning, hydroelectric and, to a far lesser extent, wind and solar."

Most OPT pundits belittle the prospects of renewable energy - "too many energy fantasists", says Ferguson. Most accept the revival of nuclear power as inevitable, but insist that the drawbacks, especially the hazards of radioactive waste, make it a least-worst option and no substitute for curbs on population.

Ferguson, who sits on teenage pregnancy panels, points out that, with 40,000 such births a year, the UK leads Europe in the field, "beating even Holland - and we are six times worse than Holland".

The trust shows little embarrassment at sharing some of its platform with anti-immigrant agitators. "We have nothing in common with the racists, and if there are social problems of immigration we don't get into that," says John Guillebaud, researcher in reproductive health at University College London, who is co-chair of OPT. "Genuine asylum seekers and others reasonably admitted can be black, khaki, purple or green, as long as we bring immigration and emigration into balance and control teenage pregnancies over five to six generations. Given the below-replacement average family size chosen by women in this country, that could bring the UK to 30 million by 2130."

He agrees that restricting immigration could worsen Britain's already problematic age structure, and "we may give up economic advantage in excluding potential workers who are promising, or willing to do jobs we ourselves don't want to do - but here the end would justify the means: we have to think of the bigger picture. Increasing the population of a seriously overcrowded country is just crazy."

Rosamund McDougal, a family planning expert and a co-chair of OPT, argues that the race issue is "simply irrelevant".

"I'd rather have 40 million people in the UK and half of them black than 100 million all white," she says. "We can't affect the death rate - we can't go around shooting people. What we can do is cut down unwanted births and immigration that we cannot sustain."

At last, she thinks, the message is getting through to government. "We were unheard of, our emails got no reply, then the penny dropped," she says. "Defra [the Department of the Environment, Food and Rural Affairs] used to be hostile, but now wants our input on rural scenarios; we argue that the notion of farmers as paid keepers of the landscape is nonsense because we're going to need the land for energy."

Best of all, a letter arrived from the Treasury promising that the current review of the sustainable development strategy will "consider what the challenges are, including in relation to trends in population and lifestyles".

Has the penny dropped?
